review_blob: 650 ml in Phillips unusually-shaped, quickly-narrowing neck bottle,from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in my Great Western 590 ml convex glass. Pours an orangey-amber shade with generous fine, slow carbonation and a smooth milky cap that holds together like dense, top-notch meringue. Loads of bright grapefruit, orange, and citrus with a side of fresh piney hop notes on the nose; on the tongue, juicy citrus and tree fruit in spades with only after-sip bitter touches. Smooth, silky, and clean-finished with that refreshing little bitterness to swipe the palate clean. A simple-profiled but smashingly enjoyable DIPA that even the hop-nave can love.

Single 355 ml bottle from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in an old-school Molson Light-labeled pilsner glass. Pours a light golden straw hue with copious streams of rapid carbonation and just a thin film of head. Rice over other grains, apple juice sweetness, grassy, woody hops, and mild skunk (despite this being in an amber bottle) on the nose; faint but inoffensive adjunct lager-ness with noticeable minerals that reminds me of Tsingtao or an NA German pils. Watery as water and just as drinkable. Id probably prefer this by a hairs-width over any popular but stinky cerveza...Im weird like that. Dull stuff that fits the bill for when you want a dull beverage, or as an extinguisher for fiery Asian cuisine.

Single 650 ml bomber bottle from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a Great Western-labeled 590 ml/20 oz. concave-sided glass, a recent find at Value Village. Pours a beautiful, clear cherry reddish-copper hue with plenty of fine, slow-moving carbonation, and generous, meringuey, well-retained off-white head, leaving soapy lace islands. Its gloriously aromatic even as I wait for the froth to settle so I can continue pouring, offering up toasty malt and oats, peach cobbler, other citrus, red berries, and fresh piney hints, apples, cinnamon, and, surprisingly (perhaps due to the glass wide mouth releasing all the ales aromas), a saucy, spice and basil tomato hit...frankly, its making me hungry as much as thirsty. The flavors saturate the tongue in practically the reverse order of aromatic appearance, and the overall presentation is truly a rich "meal-in-a-glass". Moderately thick and creamywith just a light and pleasant toasty lingering afterwards.
beer_name: Nelson Full Nelson Organic Imperial IPA

review_blob: 500 ml can from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a straw-golden color with light, fine carbonation and a fine, milky head that leaves just a few lace spots as it vanishes. Nose holds fine, light bready grain and lemony, herbal hops with small touches of fresh grass; flavor is much the same - faint toastiness and a grazing of bitterness, with lemon, lime, and faint, fresh, green hops. Thin-bodied, lightly slick, fine finish. Another unspectacular but very drinkable and pleasant Eurolager imported from Austria, as can be seen by the many languages on the can. (As an aside, I noticed that a can of Lwenbrau with similar multilingual packaging was noticeably better than a domestic L, which looked identical in powder blue and gold, but without the three dozen names for "beer".)

500 ml can from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a light golden straw color with light and short-lived carbonation and a fluffy, milky head that retreats to leave thin lace islands. Aroma is primarily a clean herbal, green noble hop and lightly honeyed grain profile, while the flavor is a mildly bitter, crackery malt with orange and lemon zest/marmalade, and the sip finishes with a herbal, peppery touch. Thin-bodied, and the bitterness only lasts for the briefest of moments. Steam Works definitely has a lock on good pilsner flavor, and its eminently quaffable at a pleasing price.

500 ml can from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a slightly burnished golden hue with fine, active carbonation and a milky head that leaves fine lace rings and webbing. Aroma holds fresh and very pleasant bready and mildly toasty grains with clean citrus and herbal hops, with a light, fresh grassy sidenote. On the tongue, the malts come forth with green herbal, lemon, lime, and orange riding alongside, with a flicker of red apple and pepper at the end of the sip. It has a nice little bit of creamy body and finishes very cleanly and dryly. One of the best Eurolagers, whose goodness requires none of the hype of its better-promoted peers like Heineken or Becks. Prost!

500 ml can from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a reddish-golden hue with light, fine carbonation and a milky head, leaving thin lace rings. Nose proves light, bright, and fresh, with lemon, lime and grapefruit, whiffs of tropicals, and light buttery toast; on the tongue, the warm toasty elements emerge to match the pace of the soft citrus. A little thick, and the citrus lingers briefly. A pleasant and very accessible pale ale that feels a lot like an ISA in all aspects but its 5.2% ABV.

500 ml can from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a bright golden hue with fine carbonation and a tall, milky head, leaving rings of fine lacing. Aroma is strongly grassy and earthy/herbal with apple juice and bready malt; flavor is apple-juicy sweetness, light random fruitiness, and faint malts with a mild lingering bitterness. Thin, finishes dryly. Its a generally confused kind of lager, but not a terribly offensive one, either.

Single 355 ml can from a broken variety case from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a dark golden hue with fine, light carbonation and a soapy white cap that leaves a few spots of lace as it retreats. Toasty malt with grassy, earthy hop notes and a slight hint of vegetal on the nose. Flavor is fairly abundant with crackers, grass, and a spice hit on the back of the tongue. Slightly oily, clean finish. Some metallic aftertaste. Not altogether bad!

355 ml can from a six-pack from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a brilliant golden hue with fine, moderate carbonation and a soapy, short-lived white head that leaves an island of webby lace. Aroma is of biscuity malt and hay/grass, with woody noble hops; flavor is lightly honeyish, toasty-crisp, fine, with that nice peppery pilsner note at the end of the sip. Thin, clean-finished. Central City and Red Racer deliver an excellent and very quaffable brew to compete with pils peers like Fernies Project 9.

Single 473 ml can from Liquor Depot, served in a pint glass. I love the CTV sitcom "Corner Gas", so a beer that appears to be branded after the comedy is an instant impulse purchase for me. Pours a deep reddish-caramel hue with active carbonation and a smooth, faintly tan head. Crackery, toasty grains and honey greets the nose, with a touch of earthy, herbal hops. Flavor consists of smooth, buttered rye toast with honey and a bit of marmalade, with a mild prick of noble hop bitterness. Slightly creamy, thick, and chewy. While I later learned that the beers "Dog River" name is related to a Saskatchewan rugby club rather than "Corner Gas" itself, Im just happy to report that the brew is delicious and doesnt rely on mere gimmickry of a familiar title. Strangely enough, the denizens of the TV town of Dog River in "Corner Gas" are shown almost exclusively imbibing Old Style Pilsner...
beer_name: District Dog River Bavarian Dark Lager

review_blob: 355 ml can from a Granville Island winter sampler, served in a weissbier vase. Pours a light coppery shade with an off-white, short-lived head. Did not notice carbonation. Aroma bodes unwell with overwhelming vanilla over some hardly-identifiable malts; flavor is so cream soda-like and vanilla-dense it nauseated me close to spewing. Did not notice palate. This is a definite drainpour and a reminder to avoid any "winter ale" - see my review of Tree Brewings Vertical Winter Ale. Why would you want to oversaturate perfectly good beer with this "winter" flavoring nonsense? Ho ho oh hell no.

Single 341 ml bottle, served in a weissbier vase. This is the final review of beers taken from 2015 Christmas variety cases. The bottle literally gushed froth upon opening, creating some spillage. On me. Fairly large streams of active carbonation could be seen in both bottle and glass, while the brew itself is an orangey-straw yellow, hazy, and with a fairly long-lived meringue head and gobs of soapy lace. Some dark specks of particulate are visible after the bottle is poured. The very strong and overripe aromas of tropical tree fruits (mostly pineapple over banana), perfumey candy, vanilla, and plasticky (bandaids?) bubblegum are unavoidable, especially when its all over your pants. The flavor mirrors the aroma, is moderately sour and quite dry upon the sip, but lingers on the palate a few moments. Im rather confused - I dont know what to observe. Anyway, the style is definitely not my scene, and Ill defer judgement to those who have more saison experience.

355 ml bottle from a six-pack from Sobeys Liquor, served in a footed Rickards-branded pint. Pours a clear orangey-light amber, with plenty of active carbonation streams, and a meringue-puffy, smooth, milky, well-retained head, leaving lots of fine lace webbing. Aroma is lots of fresh, juicy lemon and grapefruit citrus, with gentle perfumey and flowery hops, and flecks of pine; the sip inundates the tongue with the same complex with a nicely balanced bitterness. A little thick, with a brief finish. Why a hop-head like myself waited this long to try this, I have no good excuse. The hyperbolic labeling may have made me think that it was a one-dimensional bitter bomb, when its quite enjoyable and well worth trying.

Single 12 oz. bottle from the last of the cracked-open holiday cases from Sobeys Liquor, served in a nonic pint. I was going to make this review a kind of David Bowie tribute, until I realized that "Boris the Spider" was a song by the Who! I was thinking the Spiders from Mars...DOHHHH!! But I swallow my goof, change my analogies on the fly, and press forward. Pours a completely opaque deep, dark chocolate brown, but with some flumes of carbonation visible from the very inside of the glass, and a pearly cocoa head with a brief retention, settling to just the top of the beer, and leaving some lace rings. Aroma is heavy with dense, dark chocolate, dark-roast coffee, dark preserved fruit like raisins, currants, and dates, roasty malt, and some fragrance of citrus. Toasted nuttiness, too. The sip delivers a wonderful, mouth-filling, thick, chewy, creamy texture for the roasted malts, cocoa, coffee with touches of cream, and nuts, all blanketing the fruit profiles, and including a nice, palate-awakening level of coffee-like bitterness. The slightest flicker of heat reminds you of its 10% abv Imperial Russian stout pedigree. Nothing off; no meat- or soy sauce-like traits. Dont fall into arachnaphobia; enter this spiders parlor and let yourself willingly surrender to its luxuriant, luscious web.

Single 355 ml bottle from opened leftover Christmas sampler cases from Sobeys Liquor, served in a pint glass. Pours a mildly hazy straw yellow that clears in time, with some fine, slow, widely dispersed carbonation streams, and a short-lived, milky head that retains only a skiff of foam, and leaves somewhat sudsy lace patches. Aroma has soft tropical and red fruits prominent, with faint touches of banana, bubblegum, and clove, as well as whispers of malt. Flavor is similar; a mildly sweet tropical punch kind of flavor with a small malt backbone, a tiny amount of bitterness, and the slightest flicker of heat in the throat. Moderately chewy and creamy-textured, with a brief finish. You could call this a "tripel on training wheels" for those like me who dont care to have my taste buds smashed in with super-sweet and/or overripe candy, gum, banana, and tropical flavors. I really enjoyed it - the drinkability of this 9.2% abv ale is off the scale, with nothing to keep your sips paced or governed - but others may bemoan the softness and lack of other aroma and flavor notes. For me, though, its irresistable.

2015 vintage (7.3% abv) 355 ml single bottle from a broken Christmas case from Sobeys Liquor, served in my Dos Equis highball glass. Pours a somewhat hazy, cola-caramel hue, with low carbonation, and a noticeably tan head bespeckled with pearly bubbles. Aroma is deep into toasted and roasted malt and cereal grains, with citrus zest, raisins and currants, and some caramel peeking out. Flavor puts forth a larger, and quite appealing, lightly sweet fruitiness with no sour or bitter notes, laid upon a hefty backbone of toasted malts. Medium thickness, creamy on the tongue, and takes just a little time to finish. It may be lacking in liveliness and depth for a holiday brew, but I like this a lot - its an inviting stack of breakfast toast with preserves in a glass - and is worth seeking out.

Single 341 ml bottle from leftover Advent Calendar beer cases from Sobeys Liquor, served in my tall Dos Equis glass with nucleation points. Pours a dark reddish-caramel hue, with moderately lively carbonation, and a long-lasting, light tan head of smooth, bubbly foam, with plenty of even lacing. Nose holds rye toast with orange marmalade, dark fruit simmered in a bit of spirits, caramel, and other tree fruits. Flavor exhibits smooth and somewhat restrained malts with a small amount of citrus zest and raisin as backup. Thin-bodied, with a dry finish. Not at all what I assumed it would be (an ale with more Christmasy notes), and lacking in expected oomph and depth of character, but a very drinkable and pleasant year-round brew nevertheless.

Single 355 ml can from broken-up Christmas sampler cases from Sobeys Liquor, served in a pint glass. Pours a hazy golden straw yellow, with streams of active carbonation, and a brief milky head. Nose is sweet banana, bubblegum, clove, other very ripe tropical fruit - all standard for a tripel. Flavor has pronounced sweet banana and candy, with a welcome lack of alcohol heat. Goes down like a soft drink. Thin-bodied, and aftertaste lingers very briefly. Very well-done, but not really my thing.

12 oz. (no damn fruity metric used here! Merica! Okay, only joshing...) single can, probably from a Christmas sampler case, served in a pint glass. Pours a moderately hazy orangey-straw hue with streams of fine carbonation, with a smooth white head and copious sudsy lace. Loads of fresh citrus, with prevailing lemon, and a certain grassiness on the nose; likewise on the tongue, with hints of pine. A strong and slightly burny astringency/bitterness. Thin-bodied, clean-finishing. Another good IPA for the list, but needing some clawback on that aforementioned "zing".

2015 vintage (10.1% abv) single 355 ml bottle from broken-up holiday cases from Sobeys Liquor, served in a funky Dos Equis glass. Pours a shade of amber similar to dilute cola, with many fine streams of carbonation, and a light tan head topped with bubbles like just-poured milk, and generous lacy lace. Delivers a big aroma of candy, clove, bubblegum, banana and other very ripe tropical fruit, and what I interpret as fragrant wood. The warming is instantaneous with the sip; as I go, softer candy, spice, and tropical fruits, wood, some toast, and even a little more heat to govern my intake of this Yuletide bruiser. Thick, and a moderate lingerer on the palate. Not my style of Christmas ale, but seems to be executed well and befitting the season, as I finished it happily enough. What will 2016 bring?

Single 341 ml bottle taken from the unsold Christmas case leftovers from Sobeys Liquor, served in a nonic pint. Pours a deep reddish-brown hue with moderate carbonation and a smooth tan head, leaving a few lace rings. Aroma has an interesting combination of candied fruit and earthy hops poking through a dense malt base, while the flavor is of plenty of nutty malt, rye toast with bittersweet lemon marmalade, and cola caramel. Smooth and just a little thick, with a brief, clean finish. A solid brown ale, akin to a Newcastle, but with additional flavor notes. Its eminently drinkable, so be aware of its 7.2% alcohol oomph.
beer_name: Grizzly Paw Ursa Major Brown Ale

review_blob: Single 355 ml bottle from a leftover Christmas "Advent Calendar" sampler case from Sobeys Liquor, served in a nonic pint. Pours a moderately hazy, deep reddish-copper hue, very Christmasy, with moderate carbonation and a smooth head of well-retained tan foam, with generous lace. Toasted malts and grains, caramel, and fresh red fruits with a soft vinous and spiced character greet the nose. Flavor is moderately and very pleasantly dense, with liquor-soaked dark fruits and mulled citrus merging with toasty cereals, caramel, vanilla, and chocolate. Moderately thick and creamy texture, with the flavors lingering briefly, and a soft warmth to fend off winters chill. A very merry and tasty treat for the holiday season; leave this out for the Santa in your life Christmas Eve, and hell/shell be extra-good to you, guaranteed.

473 ml can from a sampler four-pack from Sobeys, served in a pilsner flute. Pours a nice yellow-amber shade with moderate, slow-rising carbonation, leaving a head of meringue-like white, which then leaves spatters of lace. Nose holds nice and generally fresh citrus and perfumey hops, balanced with sweet toasty cereals; flavor-wise, the hops and malt are in balance, although the overall flavor is muted. Thin, with a fairly clean finish. This is probably my favorite of the four varieties in this taster package from Lake of Bays, but each one needs some finessing to make them great examples of microbrewery art. Also, four is too many to attempt to review in one sitting; Im definitely off my game tonight with my deScriptions. I promise to improve.
beer_name: Lake of Bays Crosswind Pale Ale

review_blob: 473 ml can from a sampler four-pack from Sobeys, in a pilsner flute. Pours a bright, moderate amber hue with light carbonation and a puffy, milky head that retains well and leaves plenty of lacy lace. Aroma is a nice burst of citrus and piney hops, somewhere between fresh and dusty, with a small amount of floral that sits with the no-nonsense malt. Flavor is highly citrus, all grapefruit and lemon, with a soft astringency, and the sip ends like a lightly-sweetened iced tea, of all things. Thin-bodied, and the initial astringency keeps your mouth watering a few moments. Good, but it could be great with its rougher edges knocked off and the overall presentation freshened.

473 ml can from a sampler four-pack from Sobeys, in a pilsner flute. Pours a moderate reddish-amber with light carbonation and a slight mocha-tinged head that leaves rings and islands of lace. 

(While checking color and carbonation with a flashlight, I pointed the light from behind the glass, and noticed that this ale is full of fine particulate. It leaves me wondering if my glassware has been clean enough lately, if I ought to be doing this every time to check beer for clarity and floaty bits, and/or if my OCD is making a return, as a new worry about "theyre putting dirt in my beer"...)

Aroma has a surprising amount of dusty flowery and herbal hops above the lightly toasty malt with a sweet citrus fruit spread. Flavor is earthy and peppery, the malt going from sweet to almost a bit savory, with the preserves-like citrus fruit rounding it out. A bit thick, with a clean, dry finish. Good, but could use some refinement.
beer_name: Lake of Bays Spark House Red

review_blob: 473 ml can from a sampler four-pack from Sobeys, in a pilsner flute. Pours a moderately chill-hazed, yellowy-orange with lots of small-bubbled, slow-rising carbonation, creating a short-lived, milky, pearly, quickly-vanishing head that leaves no lace. Aroma has a goodly amount of malt and cereal present, with whiffs of vegetal, grass, and paper; flavor is...urk...wet, moldy cardboard and dry, dusty newsprint, with dirty vegetal sourness throughout the mouth and a related bitterness brushing the edges of the tongue. Theres no lager-ish sweetness or cereals, nor a recognizable hop character, that I can tell, but there is a hint of a "chemical stripper", like nail polish remover or WD-40. Feels thin, a tad oily, and has a lingering metallic tang. Bizarre flavor, although not sickening enough to be a drain pour. Ill give them one good mark for being a dry, noticeably un-sweet lager. Still, its really unpleasant, enough so that I cant recommend it. Why do microbreweries have such difficulty fashioning a palatable lager?
beer_name: Lake of Bays Rock Cut Baysville Lager

review_blob: Pint on tap at Local Public Eatery, downtown Medicine Hat. Poured a brownish-ruby hue with very little head. Slightly dusty floral and piney hops, with astringent grapefruit, and some light malt wandering in-between. Thin-bodied; short, clean finish. Good, although Id hoped for a fresher, broader hop profile.

500 ml can, served in a large weissbier vase. Pours a deep coppery-red with moderate carbonation and a smooth tan head that only retains briefly and leaves no lace. Aroma is super-dense and very woody, smoky, spicy, and earthy, with huge vinous, dark fruit, and fruit zest elements; flavor is identical, medicinally syrupy and overpowering, with a moderately thick body and plenty of lingering warm alcohol down the throat. I find it too difficult to drink; it reminds me of an overdone Christmas pudding. Ill have to call this a drainpour, and I refer you to other, more seasoned tasters to determine if this bock is up your alley.

500 ml can from Sobeys Liquor, served in a wheat beer vase. Pours a clear and bright golden hue, with light carbonation, and a creamy, milky-white froth that retains well and leaves soapy lace rings, which soon evaporate. Aroma is primarily malt and adjunct cereals, with sweet apple juice, a (mercifully small) vegetal presence, and grassy, herbal-ish hops. Flavor leans a little more heavily into the sweet corn cereal, sour vegetal, and earthy noble hop facets. Thin-bodied and dry-finished. Its an average Eurolager, with good and bad traits common to the type; on the whole, I enjoy them more than big-brewery domestics, and find their flaws less noticeable and noxious. Then again, perhaps Im being subconsciously swayed by the cachet of Euro cans, with their big, round-sounding, good-and-woody names ("Tuborg...Tu-BORG...Tuborg GOLD..."), vibrant colors, smart graphics, basic info printed in multiple languages, umlauts aplenty, and 160 ml more beer.

500 ml bottle from a promo pack, the last one on the shelves at my local Sobeys Liquor, and gracing the included half-litre weissbier vase. (Great glass; it more than makes up for having to turn down a heavy Paulaner litre promo mug last year.) Pours a hazy, deep straw hue with moderate carbonation and a beautifully fine, creamy, meringue-like head of bright white. Aroma is of fresh, delicate wheat, accompanied by lemon and pineapple and touches of banana and peach; the sip holds the same elements, with just enough extra banana and pineapple, and a mild hint of pepperiness. A grassy noble hop presence peeks through both. Silky, light-bodied, pleasant finish. I thought lager was the only belle of the beer ball for Oktoberfest, but this very happily corrects me. Everything is in balance, which I greatly appreciate - with too much fruit, the style can be cloying.

341 ml bottle from a winter sampler 12-pack, christening a new Erdinger Oktoberfest 500 ml vase. Pours a nice reddish-brown hue, but not quite ruby-like as promoted, with only two small, sputtering streams of carbonation and a pillowy head of amber-tinged white with heavy rings and strands of lace. Aroma mostly holds somewhat dusty flowery and citrus hops, along with malty toast spread with a marmalade melange and a sprinkling of brown sugar; the flavor is heavier on brown ale-ish, slightly sweet roasted malt, with dusty, perfumey hops trailing behind. My tongue is left a little confused. Definite chewiness and a silky texture. While amber/red ales and IPAs are two big favorites on my styles list, and I was expecting something rather amazing, it feels a little like the combination of the types compromises both sides of the equation. It reminds me of a pint of Harp draft lager with a little Guinness stout floated on top; while initially harmonious, as you sip through and the two combine, matters get muddled. Nothing deal-breaking; its a nice pick for a summer-autumn-winter style transition. Id just prefer one or the other.

355 ml can from a Granville Island sampler twelve-pack from Liquor Depot, served in a small glass mug. Pours a clear, orangey amber with very light carbonation and an off-white, pearly head that leaves lace pearls behind. Aroma is a balance of slightly sweet, toasty malts and a peculiar earthy hop character; the flavor mirrors this. Theres some caramel and molasses as well. Slightly thick body with a brief bitterness. Nothing terrible, but not my style of ale.
beer_name: Granville Island English Bay Pale Ale

review_blob: 355 ml can from a summer sampler 12-pack from Liquor Depot, served in a small glass mug. Pours a downright beautiful, clear honey-like golden hue with very faint carbonation and a pillowy white head that retains well and leaves streaks of lace. Aroma is of slightly sweet cereals and grassy hops, but the flavor has more malty character than expected; not super-sweet, but crisp and dry instead. Body is thin, but finishes cleanly. Seems to have some Vienna influence. Altogether, its a very nice lager that suits my tastes for less sweet pale beers.

Single 330 ml bottle from Sobeys Liquors seconds basket, served in a nonic pint. Pours a clear, gleaming golden yellow with widely-dispersed light carbonation (no single streams) and a pearly, short-lived, milky white head, leaving light rings of lace. The nose is a standard, cleanish lager, with mildly sweet cereals and whiffs of maltiness and grassy hops. Flavor is mild, and very much so for a 5.4% abv beer - theres very little sweetness to its generally agreeable cereals profile. There also appears to be a tiny amount of alcohol heat present. Thin, slick, and finishes cleanly. Pretty good! I find that most Italian and Spanish beers have flavor quirks that turn me off, but I find none here. Its no flavor bomb at all, but Id be more than happy to have this around to quaff, whether or not I needed to avoid gluten. Thumbs up!

355 ml can from a six-pack from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a bright, clear medium amber shade with moderate carbonation and a pearly white head that retreats to leave fronds of lace. Aroma is primarily of lemony/limey citrus and juicy resinous hops, with fresh, light malt winding its way around and tying things together; flavor is a good balance of lemon and pine hoppiness and faintly sweet malt. Thin and dry-finished, with a soft bitter bite. Another nicely-done, balanced ale...I am absolutely loving the beers in the ISA category on the whole. A pedantic part of me feels an ABV maximum between 3-4% ought to be a strict criterion for the "Session" designator...but if the malt-to-hops ratio is within reason and the beer is generally good, why fuss with a percentage point or two? Just bring it on.

355 ml can from a tasters twelve-pack from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Second in a line of four Bowen Island/Kamloops Brewery craft brews. Pours a reddish-cola shade, with light carbonation. The initially smooth head of off-white quickly vanishes, leaving small spots of lace. Aroma has a muted hop presence for a pale ale, with only faint citrus and earthiness. The bready malt is restrained as well, on the level of an ISA. The sip presents softness all around in malt, hop, and bitterness; the malt toasty, the hop winey, the bitterness just a tiny flick of the tongue. Thin, with a dry finish. Labeled as an Extra Pale Ale, it better befits the designation of a session ale in its overall balance and character. Not spectacular, but very nice and quaffable all the same. So far, in my latest tasting spree, I havent had a bum beer yet. I hope to maintain the streak...

355 ml can from a sampler twelve-pack from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a clear, brownish-amber hue (not what Id expect for a blonde ale), with light carbonation and a smooth head of off-white froth with fair retention, leaving rings of lace. Nose holds light toasted malt with gentle sweetness, along with muted hop notes of light earthiness and wine. Flavor is nicely reminiscent of amber ale, with broad, soft, gently sweet maltiness touched with red fruit; nice, but it could use a wee bit of spice for depth of character. Just a speck above merely thin-bodied, and with lingering malt aftertaste. This beer knows my weaknesses for amber and reddish ales, and exploits them well. I cant say I can detect the added hemp, nor would I know what it brings to the flavor profile, but if its at all responsible for this beers light, smooth maltiness, its a marvelous addition. Nice and drinkable.

500 ml can from Sobeys Liquor, served in a goblet. Pours a clear, light cola-caramel shade, with moderate carbonation, and a creamy, smooth, well-retained head of light mocha that leaves curtains of lace. Aroma is a rich, dense, toasty maltiness, with dark wood, deep red berries, and cinnamon with brown sugar. The flavor presents interesting and delectable hints of whiskey aged in lightly charred oak amidst its softly sweet malt panorama, like a more restrained Innis & Gunn offering. Theres caramel and vanilla flourishes as well. Creamy texture and moderately chewy, with a gently lingering finish. A superb example of the wonderful results when maltsters and brewers recombine their efforts. Malterrific beer!

355 ml can from a sixer purchased at Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a clear, bright light copper hue with active, moderate carbonation streams, and an off-white cap that retreats after holding strong for a few minutes, leaving a few bubbly lace webs and rings. The aroma immediately tantalizes, with hops presenting bright citrus and sweet berries, moderately strong, and somewhat like fruit punch. A moderate current of toasted malt weaves its way in between. The flavor sneaks in an unexpected bite of resinous bitterness, sandwiched with grapefruit and cherry, that happily settles back after the initial sips, and the warm toast of the malts coasts along in turn. A little bit thick, with a softly lingering bitter pine note. The overall impression suggests an India Session Ale, but with an added 0.5% punch above 5% abv. Like Red Racer ISA, a similarly configured favorite beer, this ale does a fine job of balancing maltiness and hoppiness in a eminently drinkable and enjoyable whole. I feel blessed to have found three new affordable favorites for my go-to list. Yay me! Yay beer!

355 ml single can from the remainders bin at Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a clear, dark yellow-amber shade, with moderate carbonation bubbling up in a pair of streams, and a crackling, pearly, briefly-lived white head - it looks rather ghetto. Aroma is a clean, mildly sweet cereal and malt melange - your basic decent pale lager profile. Then, surprisingly, the flavor dispenses with cereal sweetness almost altogether, for a dry, delicate, pilsner-like flavor and bitterness located almost exclusively at the front of the tongue - very interesting, not at all expected from a budget brand, and most definitely tasty and refreshing! Silky body, with a clean, dry finish, and just a brief hit of mild bitterness at the end. Wow, this stuff is damned good! Super-drinkable, and would be more than acceptable as a session or lawnmower quencher. It has a definite "champagne beer" character, and at low cost; that combination makes me a happy man. So far tonight, Ive found two "buck-a-beers" at Real Canadian that are solid winners and new favorites; I have a few more to go, and I hope good luck remains on my side...

355 ml can from a twelve-pack from Real Canadian Liquorstore, served in a goblet. Pours a clear, light orange-amber hue, with active streams of fine carbonation, and a quickly-vanishing pearly white head. Aroma is sweet, with bready malts, caramel, maple, and honey, and with an earthy, lightly spicy hop note. Flavor is much the same; a broad, mild, and doughy malt dominance and faintly bothersome syrupy sweetness. The spice on the nose doesnt come through on the tongue, which is a bit disappointing as it would have nicely counterbalanced the honey. Nicely creamy, chewy, and with a clean finish - no long-lasting sweetness to contend with. Its initially similar to Big Rocks River Valley Red Ale (in price, packaging, and initial appearance and aromas/flavors), but, by virtue of being a lager, its much more a close, cheap cousin to Sleemans Honey Brown. Nicely drinkable and enjoyable as a budget beer, with no deal-breaking flaws, but unless you have a taste for sweet brews like me, the syrupiness will very soon become cloying. If you make amber, red, and brown beers a regular tipple, there should be no problems.

355 ml can from a 12-pack sampler from Sobeys Liquor, served in a shaker pint glass. Pours a slightly orangey straw yellow with lots of very fine carbonation and a creamy white cap that crackles and vanishes with time to leave rings and islands of lace. Aroma is similar to many lagers, with unsweetened malty cereals, and hints of buttered corn that I truly dislike in the aroma and flavor of beer. (Actually, I dont know if my nose and tongue read this correctly as "corn"; it just might be some version of biscuity or cracker-like malt.) Flavor is practically identical to most light lagers, right down to a stronger presence of the confusing and distasteful corn/biscuit flavor, with what seems to be a hint of herbal hops. Thin, and with a dry finish. I wouldnt go out of my way for this. Although labeled as a Kristallweizen, its indistinguishable from most adjunct lagers. So-so.

500 ml bottle from Sobeys Liquor, served in a tall wheat beer glass. Pours an opaque deep brown with a towering, thick, moussey, mocha-hued cap that leaves rings of lace. Aroma is deeply toasted malts with herbal hops, light sweet caramel, and vinous fruits underneath. Tiny hints of banana. Flavor features dark, bittersweet malt, with hints of dark chocolate chips embedded in banana with a breath of caramel, and light winey berries. Slightly thick, creamy, and with a clean finish. Just indulgent enough and doesnt overwhelm in any aspect. Very, very good!

500 ml bottle from Sobeys Liquor, served in a nonic pint glass. Pours a slightly hazy orange-copper shade with mousse-like foam that retains well and leaves thick lace rings. Nose is heavy with toasty malt and earthy, dusty red fruit, somewhat winey. Mmmmm...taste-wise, theres dense malt toast topped with wine-like fruits, and the earthiness isnt as noticeable. A wee bit thick, with a soft bitterness and a pleasant finish. This is a damn good bitter, one Id be happy to drink all day. It knows what aromas and flavors to present, and does not disappoint. Top me up!

500 ml bottle from Sobeys Liquor, served in a nonic pint glass. Pours a clear orange-amber hue with light, fine streams of carbonation and a puffy, solid white head that leaves zigzags of lace. My initial reaction to the aroma was "wow, this smells the way I remember how beer smelled when I was a kid", likely due to Canadians buying and consuming a goodly amount of domestic Vienna lager. Along with a solid, medium-dark malt punch is a minty, jasmine tea undercurrent, studded with dark berries; the flavor maintains the same profile, and is both gently flavorful and eminently quaffable. The slightest level of bitterness carries over briefly into a dry, clean finish. Perhaps Id be happier with stronger flavor components, but that would drive it into another style altogether, and, as it is, I could session the daylights out of this. Very refreshing and satisfying, perhaps even more so than "lawnmower lager". Lovely ale.

330 ml bottle from Sobeys Liquor, served in a tulip glass. Chimay is the one name that comes up most often when you mention Trappist ale, or so it seems. Pours a nearly opaque pumpkin-orangey brown, with a couple of visible, fine streaks of carbonation and a milky head that goes from creamy to pearly and leaves spots of lace in its wake. Aroma delivers a payload of bready malt with hints of caramel, while the hops bring deep red, winey fruits and an undercurrent of dusty herbalness. Flavor is gentle overall, focusing on its fruity, grapey, lightly sweet, vinous character on top of its toasted malts, with a touch of carbonic bite and alcohol warmth. A bit chewy with a slightly lingering finish. Subtly flavorful when it comes to its winey facets, never entering a distasteful malt liquor territory. Still, this beer puzzles me. I had expected explosions of thick malt and flurries of hops akin to Duvel Tripel Hop, but it was all a restrained, yet likeable, knock on the doors of my tastebuds. Puzzling.

330 ml bottle from Sobeys Liquor, served in a nonic pint glass. Pours like its namesake, looks the part, too, except that motor oil doesnt have a head of light mocha thats bubbly, pearly, maintains like a mofo, and leaves all manner of lace islands. Roasted barley and oats abound on the nose, with espresso, cocoa, nuts, savory soy, buttered cinnamon toast, and hints of black liquorice. Flavor is all kinds of toasty, roasty, and caramelized - bittersweet chocolate, French roast coffee with cream, hazelnuts and peanuts, and oat-and-wheat malted cereal with brown sugar and cinnamon. Rich, chewy body and a lovely aftertaste and gentle warmth with just the right staying power. Pour this into your engine and youll purr like a Jaguar all day. A truly delicious old ale that out-stouts stouts. More, please!

330 ml bottle from Sobeys Liquor, served in a nonic pint glass. Pours a bright, clear straw yellow with light, fine carbonation and a pearly off-whitecap that crackles loudly but doesnt disappear in a blink, leaving a few lace islands. Aroma is unsweetened cereals and dusty, herbal hops; flavor is moderately malty but without the sweetness of so many light lagers. Im impressed! Did not expect that. Just a touch of sweet fruitiness in the sip thats apple-like, but not acetaldehyde-y. Has a nice bit of body to it, and finishes cleanly. A very tasty and friendly lager I dont have to fly to Bangalore to enjoy. Really nice!

355 ml can from a Big Rock sampler 12-pack from Sobeys Liquor, served in a shaker pint glass. Lets see if they can match Anchor, the pioneer of the California Common style. Pours a faintly hazy, bright orangey-copper with moderate carbonation and a pearly head; color, retention, and lace were not recorded. Nose is dry, dusty, woody, earthy, and akin to mild herbal tea; seems like a rather flat profile. Flavor is kinda flat as well; papery, similar to diluted, unsweetened cold black tea, with mild herbaceous hints and a very faint bitterness. Oily texture, clean finish. Nothing disgusting, but it doesnt excite nor satisfy me, and nowhere near competing with Anchor Steam. It reminds me of the same companys Warthog mild ale - 7B might just be repackaged Warthog...
beer_name: Big Rock 7B California Common (Brewmasters Limited Edition)
